children.subject: Well, I'm sure the CS department is trying its best to accommodate as many people as possible, but the rate enrollment for CS is increasing faster than that of the resources the department can provide. Also, resources such as GSI/TA's and classrooms are difficult to increase in a short amount of time and giving like 50 student/discussion would cause a questionable drop in teaching quality. It's rather unfortunate for us to be in the middle of such change :( But yeah, hopefully they can find more space to allow many more into demanded courses. Best of luck!
Keep in mind, there is a 5% increase in tuition every year from now on.

^^ I sure hope that will also be the case for me! Personally I was interested in ML for a long time, and was thinking of pursuing it as a research track :(

The class should expand, and many people are frustrated and concerned in general, especially for this upcoming semester, that they can't register for their classes. If Berkeley CS meant not getting into half of my classes, maybe I should have gone to a different school, and getting into CS might not have any significance to me if I'm forced to take classes that are uninteresting/irrelevant to me.

What frustrates me the most was that many of the advisers and individual students in this piazza group advised us to leave CS 189 to phase II. Turned out not to be the right advice at all. Right now I guess it's too late, but this overwhelming frustration that's spewing out among students right now should not be ignored by the CS faculty and hopefully addressed/prevented in the future. If that means accepting fewer students in the major or expanding class size, I am not sure. But being turned down for the classes and topics I love should be a right, not a far fetched desire, at the top-rated CS program that Berkeley offers.
How did you get into 281A? The professor for next semester has not replied to any of my emails.
What courses do you recommend for people with interests in ML outside of CS courses? Math 104?

I believe as mentioned, there is some form of entrance exam. 

However, as mentioned, IMO, it's not a big deal if you don't get in, because (grad) classes are just meant to introduce topics and get things started. If you're interested in the pure research track, I don't think it's very good to get caught up in "I have to follow the stereotypical ML bandwagon". 
The rest has to be learned by voraciously reading down long books/complicated papers/talking to knowledgable peers, etc.

Keep in mind, 281A is also a (IMO better) replacement, and honestly suited for an introduction for a (pure) research track. It usually covers graphical models.

Furthermore, if you look at NIPS/ICML papers, you'll realize that they're far broader than just 189, or 281A, and cover a lot of outside topics. (Honestly, having an extremely strong statistics background and being generally good at 'clever math' is far more useful for research than knowing ML 'tricks'. Generating beautiful mathematical insights and knowing the deep conceptual connections between things is probably the most coveted skill. Same importance is on the ability to pick up an entire specific sub-sub-field by reading all the reference papers).

If Paul Erdos was still alive in this era, he'd make a very powerful contribution to this field. People like Noga Alon already publish a lot into COLT. 

If you take a look at some recent "best paper" awards, you'll see that some of them aren't even related to 'stereotypical ML' at all: 

Some are about algorithmic game theory; some are about learning social networks; some are about tricks with submodular functions; some are about online convex optimization and some are about bandits. Such things require a relatively high level of mathematical skill and give off somewhat more of a math olympiad feel than anything. 

Plus, none of these can even be really covered in a grad course unless the instructor is a master of the topic and was willing to actually each for a semester, so you're not really losing out. 

You should not ever base your career on just class work.

Source: I have never taken 188/189, and I didn't even know what "machine learning" was before I took 281A :)

history.content: What are the chances of 189 expanding? Currently it has a capacity of 300 students, and a waitlist of 120. Past semesters have shown that about 60 people drop, so there is no way anyone past 100 could ever get in....
history.subject: 189 expansion?
